title: Honestly, Even LCS is boring to watch
body:
Its either complete stomps and you already know who is going to win

Or its for the first 20 minutes the teams don't do anything because they know that one team fight will judge their loss

Or it is a 40+ min scrap of teams endlessly split pushing because towers are so weak (I.E. CLG vs IMT)

There is no actual mechanical play or team fights. You just see people blowing each other up.

2. NA teams are lazy when it comes to trying new things.  One of TSM's many reasons for being mediocre this year.  The Ever game was disgusting and they should've taken more grief for that loss.

This started out as a joke, but I would love to see this.     They should just allow champions to be picked only once for series of matches. Some games are still fun to watch.  Many are not.  To be fair, though, until the best of 5s start in the playoffs, we really won't know the competitive quality of this season. And instead of balancing, they are basically anointing their chosen champions.  Viewers tired of watching Elise and Rek'sai game after game?  "Take these buffs, Gragas!  Maybe Crumbzz will be able to win an LCS game!".

> Viewers tired of watching Elise and Rek'sai game after game? "Take these buffs, Gragas! 

 Are you implying that Gragas didnt need buffs? Also i dont think that Reksai and Elise suddenly became unviable after the Gragas buffs, they are still getting picked. Along with other junglers like Kindred, Graves, Lee, Udyr, Nidalee, even cheesy stuff like Rumble jungle.

 As long as a champion is distinctive enough he will always see play, unless his numbers are way off. Zac or Amumu for example arent distinctive at all (worse versions of Seju) so unless their numbers are buffed to OP status they will remain unpicked.

LCS and in general competitive play is incredibly boring to watch atm because every strategy is a 3-0 or 4-0 push in opposite lanes as long as they can do it, often pushing all the way to an inhibitor turret and occasionally even farther. It's basically a match of chicken for the first 8-10 minutes and it completely sucks.

It would be much more interesting to see actual lane matchups early on, but this isn't the optimal path to obtaining early gold gains so teams are unlikely to change this strategy unless something in the game is changed.

Seriously, this meta is pretty diverse. Poke comps are thing, as are engage comps, ADC-centric comps and pick comps.  Assassins, ADCs and tanks are playable. Mages fill their role pretty well, as do supports. Burden of vision is divided between everyone, not centered as much around support.

The rest complains about ADCs being too durable and tanks having too much damage... Seriously, you guys wanted "defensive options for ADCs" back in s4-s5, because you were paper when playing them. Old pre-rework Kog'maw had like twice as much damage, but suddently he's a problem. 

As for LCS, if you don't like don't watch, simple as that.
Why is it that the first thing people assume is that I'm being nostalgic? "Back in the old days" was a TERRIBLE time for League, I'm a support player. Every season has made my role better.

I stopped watching LCS when mains became 'whatever is strong in this meta.' That was the point where unparalleled mechanical ability with a players favourite champion was made redundant by lesser knowledge of a broken champions kit, and Riot encouraged that behaviour. 

I understand why players do it, they want their cash prize, though it became a game of 'who picks Fiora/Morgana/Elise/Rengar/<insert whoever has been dominant in any season> first?' rather than the surprise token, fan favourite pick.

DOTA's pro scene, on the other hand, allows more room for players to pick whatever they want. It's more unexpected, unpredictable and that makes it more fun to watch. The meta is solid and doesn't morph into something completely different on a few rounds of nerfs, and thus you're allowed more freedom to experiment around it. 

Riot have entered this habit of balancing their game by nerfing the strongest champions, and it's a bad habit to fall in to. The meta becomes unstable, players default to the stronger champions as their safety net and you enter this vicious cycle that effects us, the viewers.  To counteract the mess they've created, they need to start buffing other champions to balance their game for them. 

We saw this when ADC got their itemization changes, and saw the rise of armour scaling champions like Rammus and Malphite. If things were left as they were, the meta would've balanced out on its own. Less people would play ADC in every role, Rammus' and Malphite's tyranny would die out and you create a level playing field.
Instead, with Riot's infinite wisdom, Rammus and Malphite became the standout champions and received a few hits to curve their win rate and the ADC meta continued unchecked. What happened? The rise of assassins, and the assassin vs ADC meta we're lumped with now. Who can burst who down first? Boring to play, boring to watch.

Not respecting TF damage (building swift instead of merc). IMT had more damage.

The one thing that I got out of that game was that graves is far too strong and has been AND riot is not doing anything about it.

Don't forget:
- Almost always the same champions each game for the specific teams
- Every pick is a flex pick that does not flex too much
- If it is NA you have IMT win again, yay woohoo what else is happening, CLG and C9 stay second and third , no surprises here, TSM disappoints once again but remains in 4th sad that this is the normal now for them, and random outcomes that have no immediate change in playoffs unless it is a fight for 6th or last.
- Win by a land slide or throw and lose in the late game
- Late game is reduced down to who wins a team fight because death timers are seriously way too long
- Caitlyn lays down a trap line to prevent pushing
- Hey they got zz'rot portal guess that lane will auto-push a bit
So how would you fix these things?

I'm only bronze but my list:

Make towers more dangerous by adding utility not damage. Tier 1 reduces your outgoing damage by 10% (ap and ad, autos, etc). Tier 2 reduces your movespeed and attack speed as well tier 1 bonuses. Tier 3 reduces your healing stacked with t1/t2 bonuses. That way diving is not a case of "I might die" but "can I actually do it?".

Set death timers back to something normal. 60 seconds dead is immense and should happen past the 35 minute mark not before.

NERF ALL DAMAGE. All of it. Nerf stats, nerf everything. Serious moment: This game has too much damage bundled everywhere. Bought a Titanic? Grats you're now an assassin because that active resets autos unlike Ravenous or Tiamat (unless you're Riven) while having high burst. Maw has too much mr for the ad/pen it grants. Get rid of that. Steraks is just way too good, -5% would be a sizable nerf to damage while keeping its theme together (meaning the base ad bonus not something else). Reduce Reavers; cdr you can get 30% off one item which is too much. Give ap mages real ap items. Get an ad version of zhonyas and an ap version of duskblade. Nerf and Equalize- the ad metagame is too strong.

Update Binary kits even if its just 1 or 2 skills. Annie and Taric are no longer acceptable in those states. Binary kits that just say "do or do not" is not ok. Fiora is instantly lcs because she's no longer a stat check "can i kill? yes, kill. no? wait a sec". Same on Poppy. 

Review your masteries. In no case should I have to contest mastery picks that provide the same function- Deathfire and Thunderlord are too similar. You choose them based on the stats unless your kit has enough aoe application for dft to be good. Update runes and clear everyone of t1 to t2 runes, make t3 buyable at the start up for new players and rename them to just runes not tier 3 runes.

Recheck itemization. No one wants Doran Shield, but everyone wants Sword and Ring. That means the inherent value of Shield is so low thats not even worth buying to get an early advantage, whereas sword and ring are.

So on so forth. Just my thoughts :C I tend to be wrong.

I think fights are more interesting for people to watch, in general.  Hockey and chess both require strategy to win, but I feel like more people would enjoy watching a hockey game than chess.  It feels like right now, the strategy of LoL is hold out until one person on the other side makes a mistake pre-teamfight, then capitalize and win.  I think people want more back and forth, rather than one fell swoop.

When pick and ban gets predictable, you know this game has a problem. In the past, people had their legendary picks you wouldn't leave up for them, even at the expense of strong picks in the meta, Faker had his LB, INSec had his Lee Sin and Rengar and Marin had his Rumble and Maokai. In the S4 worlds, almost every team threw Lee Sin and Rengar bans at SHRC, leaving the possibility of Alistair at 90% ban rate or Zilean at 80% ban rate. Now, it's more about the picks rather than the player on the champion because of how homogeneous the  strong champions are and how far superior they are to the next tier. For example, this week, if anyone banned Kalista, you could almost guarantee a Jhin ban coming back the other way which is boringly predictable.

> And games are not always a stomp, thats simply false.

you haven't watched previous seasons then or you like the current meta which is trash.  The games are stomps.   When you can gank dive a tower and kill the adc with over half health that is a stomp.  The damage is ridiculous.  When a team fight happens early, whoever wins, snowballs and the game is over.  The towers are busted down so quick the 'strategy' you speak of is really non existent.  The strategy is blow the other team up first and don't die.  There's no real risks now.  You dive a turret you will get a kill and go away unscratched as long as you have the numbers advantage.  So predictable....

open the player builds/match history thing on the Esports game on any professional game. The part where you can stalk pros' builds..

if you click the match overview, most games tend to have a fairly constant slope until the end of the game...meaning in general the first team to take a gold advantage keeps it until they win. They grow it little by little by pressing that small advantage while the opposing team avoids any risk and consequently falls further and further behind, objective by objective. Eventually they will be forced to make a move, but the winning team dictates the game, plays to their win condition typically leaving little opening for a comeback, unless some big mistake "throw" is made

This is mostly a professional league problem...solo Q is so disorganized that unless youre playing very high elo, or you completely shat the bed and fed your lane 4+ kills, you almost always have some opportunity to come back for a win. The long death timers and weak towers give you that chance...

in pro play, however, these players are so skilled they make very few mistakes. Thus, once someone gains an advantage, they typically keep it unless they make a monumental mistake. This happens sometimes, we see gold leads flipped and big swings...but yeah mostly it's the, "first team to get a lead keeps it by playing hyper-cautiously until they everntually win through attrition"
